qas.question: What types of organizations are NPOs usually associated with?
Who does an NPO usually serve?
What do NPOs that center around community usually focus on?

answers.text: providing services to the community in general, either globally or locally

qas.question: What are member serving NPOs really focused on?
What are community serving NPOs focused on?

answers.text: a helping service for fellow citizens

qas.question: What have people come to associate the broader community with?

plausible_answers.text: an often high profile or visible aspect of the sector

qas.question: What elements make up human service programs?
What are the two main types of health services?

plausible_answers.text: in general, either globally or locally

qas.question: How do credit unions serve the community?

plausible_answers.text: benefit a particular group of people i.e. the members of the organization

qas.question: How does medical research benefit credit unions?

context: The nonprofit landscape is highly varied, although many people have come to associate NPOs with <a0_0><b5_0>charitable<a0_0/> organizations<b5_0/>. Although charities do comprise <b6_0>an often high profile or visible aspect of the sector<b6_0/>, there are many other types of nonprofits. Overall, they tend to be <b7_0>either <a1_0>member-serving or community-serving<b7_0/><a1_0/>. Member-serving organizations include mutual societies, cooperatives, trade unions, credit unions, industry associations, sports clubs, retired serviceman's clubs and peak bodies – organizations that <b9_0>benefit a particular group of people i.e. the members of the organization<b9_0/>. Typically, community-serving organizations are focused on <a2_0>providing services to the community <b8_0>in general, either globally or locally<b8_0/><a2_0/>: organizations delivering human services programs or projects, aid and development programs, medical research, education and health services, and so on. It could be argued many nonprofits sit across both camps, at least in terms of the impact they make. For example, the grassroots support group that provides a lifeline to those with a particular condition or disease could be deemed to be serving both its members (<a3_0>by directly supporting them<a3_0/>) and the broader community (through the provision of <a4_0>a helping service for fellow citizens<a4_0/>).
